bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Richard Cutts (1771-1845) was a U.S. Representative from Massachusetts, born on Cutts Island, Saco, Maine. He graduated from Harvard in 1790, beame a member of the State house of representatives, 1799 and 1800. Cutts was then elected as a Democrat to Congress, 1810-1813. Later he was appointed as superintendent general of military supplies, 1813-1817, and as Second Comptroller of the U.S. Treasury, 1817-1829.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This autograph collection consists chiefly of letters to Richard Cutts. The letters are from prominent individuals, primarily of Maine and Massachusetts and other areas of New England.

Also present are invitations from Dolley Madison and [Lydia Howard] Sigourney; a commission for Walter Coles Cutts as midshipman, signed by John Quincy Adams; a commission for Richard Cutts as a Massachusetts Justice of the Peace, signed by Governor Joshua Strong; envelopes franked by Dolley Madison (no content) and one envelope franked by President James Madison; brief genealogical materials on the Cutts family; two letters to Lucia Beverly Cutts (1851-?), grand-niece of Dolley Madison, concerning Memoirs and Letters of Dolly Madison: wife of James Madison, President of the U.S.; news clippings; an oath of Richard Cutts to perform the duties of Superintendent General of Military Supplies of the United States sworn before Joseph Forrest; obituaries for Colonel Richard D. Cutts, Dr. Harry M. Cutts; and General Richard D. Cutts (1817-1883); recepits for pew rent and a minister's salary; a poem addressed to the Honorable John Quincy Adams; a printed appeal for biographical information from Harvard graduates from John Langdon Sibley; promissory note signed by James Madison; and a silhouette fo Martha Jefferson Hackley Cutts.

did.unittitle: Henry Dearborn (1751-1829) to Richard Cutts 1803 April 19

did.unittitle: Henry Alexander Scammell Dearborn (1783-1851) to Richard Cutts 1814 May 20

scopecontent.p: Has paid the duties and freight for the articles on the brig Ramblerdestined for Mr. and Mrs. Madison; ashamed for the lack of support in Boston for the government and the war against Great Britain; believes that Russia, France, Holland, Spain, and the Italian states have the same interests as the United States in reducing the power and control of Great Britain over the ocean; also predicts another revolution in France.

did.unittitle: Joseph Delaplaine (1777-1824) to Mrs. Anna Cutts 1819 January 22

scopecontent.p: Asks for her to sit for her portrait

did.unittitle: George William Erving (1771-1850) to Anna Cutts n.y. December 19

scopecontent.p: Promises that the parcels intended for James Madison will be taken by Hazlewood Farish to Montpelier or the Orange Courthouse

did.unittitle: William Eustic (1753-1825) to Richard Cutts and George Ingels 1804-1815

scopecontent.p: Two letters as Secretary of War to Ingels, acknowledging receipts for Indian goods (1811 Dec 24); letters to Cutts include: advice on recruiting for the military force for the War of 1812 (1813 Jan 25); asks about arrangements for his passage to Europe, with a note on the verso page from Benjamin W. Crowninshield (1814 Mar 18); discusses scheme to take Montreal in the winter over the ice (1814 Jun 22); inquires about the records of the War Office and other matters following the burning of Washington by the British (1814 Sep 16); his approval of James Monroe as Secretary of War and of James Madison's speech following the attack on Washington (1814 Oct 5); asks if the account of expenditures spent on the Boston harbor and fortifications for several years could answer the critics of the government who believed Boston had been neglected (1814 Oct 19); discusses the militia bill of [William Branch] Giles (1814 Nov 25); refers to the Battle of New Orleans, "Should they stand & beat the enemy, he & they [his troops] will deserve immortality" (1815 Jan 28 & Feb 13); and describes his arrival in Holland to take up his post as minister to Holland (1815 Nov 26)

did.unittitle: J. Fairfield to Richard Cutts 1803 February 7

scopecontent.p: Writes "since the President's message they [the Federalist Party] have nothing to attend to but separation business"

did.unittitle: "A Federalist" to James Madison 1813 April 2

did.unittitle: William King (1768-1852) to Richard Cutts 1804-1810

did.unittitle: A.R. Lawrence to Jacob Barker 1813 July 20

did.unittitle: Silas Lee (1760-1814) to Richard Cutts 1802 February 7

did.unittitle: J. Mason to Richard Cutts n.d.

did.unittitle: John Young Mason (1799-1859) to unknown 1831 January [7]

did.unittitle: Prentiss Mellen (1764-1840) to Richard Cutts 1802 December 14
Hugh Mercer to James Madison 1827 July 27

scopecontent.p: Sends letter of introduction for Joseph W. [Harnum?]

did.unittitle: William Moody to Richard Cutts 1813-1814

did.unittitle: James Moorfield to Nancy Moorfield 1830 April 8

did.unittitle: James Morrison to Richard Cutts 1815 February 17

did.unittitle: Daniel Parker to Richard Cutts 1822 August 31

did.unittitle: John C. Payne to Richard Cutts 1817 November 1

did.unittitle: Major Porter to Captain Truman 1810 August 28

scopecontent.p: Requests forms to comply with the request of Mr. Eustis

did.unittitle:
William Pitt Preble (1783-1857) to Richard Cutts
1812-1817

scopecontent.p: Says that the recent elections has made him ashamed of New England, "that patriotism which animated our fathers in the revolution has fled to the backwoods of Kentucky and Ohio," disagrees with the contention that the election of DeWitt Clinton would bring peace, and promises "Fear not Massachusetts - and her satellites - she is almost ashamed to see you carry on the war without her. Forty thousand of her sons have not yet bowed the knee to Baal" (1812 Nov 23); while news of the disaster concerning the forces of James Winchester on the frontier was a terrible blow, he is encouraged by news of the destruction of the British frigate Java (1813 Feb 18); describes a large Republican convention at Alfred, Maine, and welcomes news of the victory of the U.S. Hornet over the British ship The Peacock (1813 Mar 25); mentions the American victories at York (present-day Toronto) and Fort Meigs, and admits to being open to an appointment if his abilities are needed (1813 Jun 2 & 15); and discusses the estate of Foxwell Cutts (1817 Apr 8)

did.unittitle: Joseph [Prime ?] to Richard Cutts 1813 February 21

scopecontent.p: Requests his help in securing an appointment for Franklin Greene as an officer in the army

did.unittitle: Jesse Putnam to Richard Cutts 1813 July 20

scopecontent.p: Asks for his help in applying for the office of collector at Boston

did.unittitle: Josiah Quincy (1772-1864) to Benjamin Eaton 1806 February 12

scopecontent.p: Writes concerning Eaton's petition to Benjamin Crowninshield

did.unittitle: A. Randolph to her sister, Harriet Hackley 1831 April 17

scopecontent.p: Asks for her help in completing shirts for her son George before he sails

did.unittitle: Richard Poland Randolph to Dolley Madison 1845 September 13

scopecontent.p: Writes from the Washington City Prison, relating the details of his incarceration and begging for her help

did.unittitle: Silvestre [Rebello ?] to Anna Cutts 1827 June 13

scopecontent.p: Presents Mrs. Cutts with another pack of snuff to be shared with her sister

did.unittitle: David Sewall (1735-1825) to Richard Cutts 1803 December 17

did.unittitle:
Samuel Shaw (1768-1827) to Richard Cutts
1812-1814

did.unittitle: M[argaret] B. Smith to Richard Cutts n.d.

scopecontent.p: Sends a book as a gift and thanks him for his true and sincere friendship

did.unittitle: Samuel L. Southard (1787-1842) to Midshipman Walter C. Coles 1828 August 1

did.unittitle: Robert Southgate to Richard Cutts 1803 January 30

did.unittitle: William Stackpole (1779-1822) to Richard Cutts 1812 November 19

did.unittitle: Seth Storer to Richard Cutts 1810 December 5

scopecontent.p: Has safely arrived from London at Norfolk, and asks his opinions about the future of trade with either France or England

did.unittitle: James Sullivan (1744-1808) to Richard Cutts 1804 December 8 & 30

scopecontent.p: Asks that the Cutts look out for his son, George, now visiting Washington, congratulates Cutts on the election, and believes Albert Gallatin a man of much ability

did.unittitle: Peleg Tallman (1764-1840) to Richard Cutts 1813 March 20

scopecontent.p: Sends letter of introduction for Dr. John Martin

did.unittitle: William Temple to [Anna ?] Payne 1797 February 4

scopecontent.p: Mentions the interruption of the commerce of the United States by the French and assures her that he has all of her letters and will get them to her as soon as he can find a proper conveyance

did.unittitle: George Thatcher to Richard Cutts 1802 January 20

scopecontent.p: Asks him to pay his subscription to The Universal Gazetteand send him copies of reports from Congress

did.unittitle: David Thomas (1762-1831) to Richard Cutts 1812 January 4

scopecontent.p: Forwards a request for an appointment to army by David Thomas

did.unittitle: Thomas Todd (1765-1826) to Richard Cutts 1817-1822

scopecontent.p: Reveals concerns about Monroe's appointment of John Quincy Adams and asks him to take care of some financial matters for him Washington (1817 Apr 15); three slaves and his son, Johnson, sick with typhoid fever, caused him to miss the current term of the Supreme Court, although he was anxious about changes in the judicial system (1819 Jan 31); and plans to visit Montpelier on the way home to Frankfurt, Kentucky (1822 Mar 3)

did.unittitle: Elisha Tracy (1766-1846) to Richard Cutts 1814-1815

scopecontent.p: Writes that the sons of the late Governor Roger Griswold stand accused of "holding direct intercourse with the British squadron" as an example of the treachery going on in Connecticut (1814 Mar 22); asks for help with an appointment (1815 Feb 13); and mentions the mortification of the enemies of the administration of Madison at news of the peace agreement (1815 Mar 20)

did.unittitle: Charles Turner, Jr. (1760-1839) to Richard Cutts 1814 February & July

scopecontent.p: Discusses political appointments for Massachusetts

did.unittitle: Marcia Van Ness to Anna Cutts Tuesday morning

scopecontent.p: Inquires after her health and asks if there is anything she can do for her in her illness

did.unittitle: Benjamin Waterhouse (1754-1846) to Abigail Adams [1782?] & 1816

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for her letter and pamphlet, proposes to settle in Boston, and sends his regards to the rest of her family ([1782?] Nov 5); and to Richard Cutts, offers to supply Cutts with a correct list of the newly adopted names of medicines used by the medical staff of the army, for the military supply forms, and complains at his treatment by a young surgeon at the Brownsville Hospital, now supposedly acting as an inspector of medical men and matters at Cambridge and who desires his post (1816)
